p: In addition to clinical comorbidities demographic characteristics and socioeconomic conditions also can increase the risk for influenza infections. Close human contacts in crowded housing during the influenza season, influenza vaccine uptake in a community, awareness of influenza transmission routs, and following the non-pharmaceutical prevention practices effect influenza virus spread and attack rates in population. The risk for influenza infection may also vary in individuals from different racial/ethnic backgrounds and age groups.
